data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA 2004) emphasises the requirement for effective major incident planning/management by the relevant agencies to include National Health Service (NHS) Trusts and Foundation Trusts. In this capacity, Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust, is a category one responder. This should introduce the policy i.e. why is it needed, what is the background to it etc. - just type over this text
The NHS service-wide objective for emergency preparedness resilience and response is:

To ensure that the NHS is capable of responding to major incidents of any scale in a way that delivers optimum care and assistance to the victims, and minimises the consequential disruption to health care services and that brings about a speedy return to normal levels of functioning; it will do this by enhancing its capability by work as part of a multi-agency response across organisational boundaries'. (NHS Emergency Planning Guidance 2005)

Recent events, internationally, nationally and locally, have reinforced the need to be prepared for major incidents. The increasing threat of terrorism, civil unrest and pandemic have reminded us all of the need to expect the unexpected.

Whatever the incident, our response needs to be flexible and appropriate to the need. The Plan outlines how the Trust's response dovetails with the rest of the health services in Mid and South Essex and also describes how the major incident plans of other critical agencies such as Police, Fire and Local Authorities inter-relate to ensure an effective, co-ordinated and efficient response by all.
As Chief Executive, I accept executive responsibility for Emergency Planning as defined by the Civil Contingencies Act (2004).
This Major Incident Plan has been adopted and approved by the Trust Board.
Clare Panniker Chief Executive
The Civil Contingencies Act

Under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA), all NHS-funded organisations are required to plan for, respond to and recover from a wide range of incidents and emergencies that could impact on health or patient care while maintaining key services to patients. These could be anything from extreme weather, an infectious disease outbreak, a surge in demand, or a major transport / industrial incident.
As a category 1 responder under the CCA (those at the core of an emergency response) we have a statutory duty to;
Undertake risk assessments
Develop and maintain emergency plans
Develop and maintain Business Continuity Plans
warn, inform and advise the public in the event of an emergency
Share information with other responders to enable greater coordination
Co-operate with other responders.

The NHS England and Improvements Emergency Preparedness Resilience Response (EPRR) Framework, is the strategic national guidance for effective health emergency planning for all NHS organisations in England, and places the responsibility of emergency preparedness with the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) within each NHS organisation. This, together with the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA) places a greater emphasis on major incident planning within the NHS.
Within the Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust the Deputy Chief Executive is designated as the Senior Responsible Officer (SRO) for Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response.
Scope
The Scope of this plan is to:
Provide clear information to staff on Incident/Major Incidents and EPRR.
Provide staff with clear guidelines on how to respond to an Incident/Major Incident.
Provide staff with clear guidelines on how an Incident/Major Incident will be managed.
To provide the hospital's clinical response
To liaise with other agencies/organisations in order to manage the impact of the incident.
To maintain communications for existing patients and those from the incident, friends and family, the local community, the media.
To ensure the hospital continues its essential functions throughout the incident.
Protect the health and safety of staff responding to the incident

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response Strategic Group

The EPRR Groups will review and approve all EPRR plans and policies as well as receive  the  findings/monitoring  report  and  will  monitor  adherence  to  the  NHS England and Improvements Core Standards across the Trust.
Senior Responsible Officer (Deputy Chief Executive)

The Senior Responsible Officer is the Accountable Emergency Officer (AEO) for EPRR for ensuring that effective arrangements are in place for responding to a major incident and that these arrangements are regularly reviewed, and that a Major Incident Plan is in place that links into the organisations arrangements for business continuity that it is built on the principles of risk assessment, co-operation with partners, emergency planning, communicating with the public and information sharing.
The Senior Responsible Officer (or nominated deputy) would usually lead the response and represent the service at the multi-agency Strategic Co-ordinating Group.
Clinical Directors, Directors of Operations, Deputy Directors Operations and Associate Directors
The Clinical Directors, Directors of Operations, Deputy Directors of Operations and Associate Directors promote and oversee the implementation of the EPRR, strategy and plans. This involves:
Supporting the development and implementation of Emergency Planning and Resilience capabilities in preparation for an emergency situation
Ensuring an Impact Analysis is completed for their areas of responsibility and specific service areas as deemed necessary
Ensuring a Resilience Plan (including Emergency Planning and Business Continuity) are in place for their areas of responsibility.
Senior Managers On-Call

The senior manager On-Call will take responsibility for leading the Trust's response to an emergency and will act as tactical leader (Silver Command). The role of the Senior Manager is to act as a conduit between Operational (Bronze) and Strategic (Gold) Command and allocation of Trust resources.
Clinical Site Coordinator
The Clinical Site Coordinator will take immediate charge of the emergency situation and will continue to be in charge until relieved by a Senior Manager.
Security Management

The Security Manager is responsible for ensuring that the Trust's security systems and staff are able to respond to incidents within the Trust and instigate Lockdown procedures in order to protect the Trust and its staff.
Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response and Team

To support the Senior Responsible Officer in the discharge of their duties for EPRR in accordance with the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 and the Health and Social Care Act 2012, and act as tactical advisor.

Ensure that the organisation meets its statutory obligations under the CCA and complies with all relevant EPRR guidance for the NHS, including non-statutory guidance that accompanies the CCA and also for business continuity and resilience preparedness;

Develop and deliver the organisation's emergency preparedness and resilience function, improve standards for preparedness across the organisation and provide leadership on specialist emergency preparedness, resilience and response issues; Ensure that EPRR corporate responsibilities are met and provide assurance to the organisation's Board that it complies with relevant legislation and guidance (as summarised by the NHS England and NHS Improvement Core Standards for EPRR);

Developing and contributing to professional relationships within the organisation, with other commissioners and NHS funded organisations and multi-agency partners that facilitate the continual development of EPRR arrangements;
Lead the development and implementation of EPRR delivery plans;
Ensure appropriate representation at local health resilience partnerships (LHRPs), local resilience (LRFs) and their associated sub-groups and work streams;

Coordinate emergency preparedness and training exercises for the organisation and with resilience partners; and work with communications staff to ensure an appropriate communications and media response by the NHS to significant events and emergencies
Executive Directors

The Executive Directors will be notified of an incident at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust through the Chief Executive Officer (or deputy Chief Executive Officer) who is informed through the Executive on call as standard.

Executive Directors will be substituted into strategic (gold) commander roles on request of the Chief Executive; otherwise they will have a role as an oversight group across the three Mid and South Essex hospitals (Basildon, Southend and Mid Essex).
The trust may request support from the Executive Directors (via the Chief Exec or deputy) in the form of a formal spokesperson to agree a joint media strategy and address the media.
Trauma networks
Broomfield Hospital is part of the East of England Trauma Network (Trauma East)
The East of England Trauma Network has been set up to ensure that patients receive the most

appropriate care at the correct time. The Network is responsible for the care of major trauma patients in the East region; covering the counties of Cambridgeshire, Bedfordshire, Essex, Hertfordshire, Norfolk and Suffolk.
Southend and Basildon Hospitals are part of the North East London and Essex Trauma Network

The London Trauma Network has been set up to ensure that patients receive the most appropriate care at the correct time. The Network is responsible for the care of major trauma patients in the South East; covering the counties of Essex, the outer edge of Hertfordshire and North East London.
London and South East England Burns Network
The burns network coordinates the burns patient clinical pathway between all providers within their network. Ensuring a whole system collaborative approach.

The network consists of four hospitals providing care for complex burn injuries; St Andrews Burns Centre at the trust being one of them. With the facilities to provide in- patient burns care for the highest level of injury complexity
Partner Agency Engagement

All incidents require some degree of engagement with partner agencies from both inside the NHS and from the wider resilience community. It is essential that communication and information sharing between responding organisations is maintained before, during and after a Major Incident or Emergency.
The key roles of partner agencies are as follows; East of England Ambulance Service (EEAST)
Saving life together with the other Emergency Services
Providing treatment, stabilisation and care of those injured at the scene
Providing appropriate transport, medical staff and resources to scene
Establishing an effective triage sieve and sort system to determine the priority evacuation needs of those injured
Nominating and alerting receiving Hospitals and informing other agencies

Provide a Hospital Ambulance Liaison Officer (HALO) to receiving hospitals where possible. HALO will have direct radio links with the scene of the incident and provide the hospitals with updated information and warns of the
arrival of casualties. Police Forces
Dealing with fatalities
Collection and preservation of forensic evidence
Collation of casualty information and informing relatives

Allocated a Police Liaison Officer to receiving hospitals; normally based within the Emergency Department, to assist in collating casualty lists and to liaise with the Casualty Bureau at Police Headquarters, Chelmsford.
If necessary, the police will be asked to help with departmental security and ensuring clear routes for emergency vehicles and duty staff.
Staff Must Remember that every major incident is a potential crime scene and all evidence must be preserved for any investigation, as far as possible
NHS England Localities
NHs England has overall command of the NHS during a major incident.
In a larger scale incident NHS England will represent all NHS partners at the multi- agency response forum called the Strategic Coordination Group (SCG).
Public Health England (PHE)

Provides an integrated approach to protecting UK public health through the provision of support and advice to the NHS, local authorities, emergency services, other arms-length bodies, the DHSC and the Devolved Administrations.
Providing public health specialist advice to NHS organisations during an incident.
Primary Care Services

Primary Care Services such as General Practice and Community Pharmacies will be required to support in a major incident. The request will be through CCGs as the commissioners. They are expected to support by:
Providing additional services for incident response as requested and commissioned
Re-deploying staff and resources to assist in incident response e.g. provision of clinical staff to Survivor Reception Centres
Reducing non-urgent referrals into acute hospital services impacted by surge capacity/increased demand e.g. Emergency Departments and Pathology
Community Care Providers
Ensure the continuation of business as usual community care provision
Provide additional services for incident response as requested and commissioned e.g. additional care within the community for patients discharged from hospitals
Re-deployment of staff and resources to assist in incident response e.g. provision of clinical staff to medical facilities or specialist clinics as appropriate
Mental Health Trusts
Supporting the wider health economy with regard to the mental health of all those individuals involved in or affected by the incident.
Support the function of Humanitarian Assistance Centres
Monitor and treat the longer-term psychological impacts of a Major Incident on all of those directly or indirectly affected.

Re-deploy staff and resources to assist in the incident response e.g. provision of clinical staff to Survivor Reception Centres, Anti-Viral collection points or other medical facilities as appropriate
Local Authority

During a Major Incident the Local Authority has a number of responsibilities for managing the needs of their local population and others who have been directly or indirectly affected by a Major Incident:

The Local Authority will support Acute Hospitals, by arranging for patients to transfer into the community/residential care for on-going treatment where possible, and create bed capacity through Adult and Children's Social Services.
Some local authorities also have the ability to provide assistance with Patient Transport and other logistical requirements.
In large scale incidents the Local Authority will lead the set-up of Humanitarian Assistance Centres, Rest Centres and Survivor Reception Centres.
The Local Authority also manages the excess death arrangements in an incident.
HM Coroner

The role of the Coroner is defined by statute. The Coroner has to determine who has died and how, when and where the death came about in relation to those bodies lying within his/her district who have met a violent or unnatural death or sudden death of unknown cause.
Fire and Rescue services

The Fire Brigade is primarily responsible for life-saving through search and rescue, firefighting and prevention, rendering humanitarian services and the detection and monitoring of hazardous materials. The Fire Brigade in partnership with the ambulance service and acute hospitals is also able to undertake Mass Decontamination should it be required.
Regional Level - NHS England and NHS Improvement (NHSEI)

NHS England and NHS Improvement has overall command of the NHS within the region during a major incident. However NHSEI will use that authority only as far is as necessary to ensure a co-ordinated response to the incident and as far as possible decisions will be delegated to NHS organisations themselves.
NHSE/I Roles include:
Assess the potential impact of all events on the NHS and the community.
Notify those NHS organisations who are not already alerted.
Co-ordinate the NHS response to emergencies.
Provide a  hour Management response.
Provide a  hour Public Health response via the on call DPH.

Provider a scientific and technical advice cell (STAC) during large incidents in consultation with Public health England (PHE). The on call Director of Public Health will be the STAC chair. The STAC will be made up of other specialists from other agencies (see section 20.13).
Provide a senior representative to act as NHS Gold at multi-agency ‘gold' co- ordinating groups.
Act as a main conduit between the health service and the Police, Security Services, MOD and Central Government.
Co-ordinate the Sector responses.
Provide specialist advice and support to the NHS and Partner Agencies.
Support other areas and the Department of Health, using national arrangements.
Co-ordinate and support all media issues and communications.
Maintain close liaison with the Department of Health at all times.
Act as a conduit for Military Aid and Special National Arrangements.
Lead de-briefings of NHS response and implement lessons learnt.
Act as a broker for mutual aid.
Request information from all NHS organisations in the form of Sitreps to inform strategic decision making and provide information to government ministers when required.
NHS Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs)
CCGs are a category Two responder and have a statutory duty to assist NHS England (East) in its response to an incident as required. It is the CCGs responsibility to:
Manage surge capacity and decant operations arising as a consequence of a major incident in cooperation with providers and other agencies, e.g. Social care.
Initiate and support the public health response to the incident if this is appropriate.
Mobilise primary care and community resources in response to the incident.
Support Acute Trusts by taking steps to relieve pressure on them.
Communicate with the media and public.
Assess the impact on health and health services of the incident.
Provide the health service input to the strategic management of the incident (may be in conjunction with Public Health England).
Arrange follow-up if needed of persons affected or exposed to risk during the incident.
Ensure that the CCG's major incident plan is co-ordinated with those of other relevant organisations.
Acute NHS Trusts
Activate major incident and Business Continuity plans for internal or external emergencies
Provide treatment and care for the injured or ill
To ensure the highest quality of care is provided to all patients
Notify NHS England (East of England) if self-declaring a Major Incident or involved in the response to a Major Incident
Notify the Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and/or Commissioning Support Unit (CSU) if self-declaring a Major Incident or involved in the response to a Major Incident
Notify Public Health England (PHE) in dealing with public health emergencies.
Work with the Emergency bed Service (EBS), NHS England and Improvements (East of England) and Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) to manage bed capacity.
Manage tertiary referrals
Maintain emergency and routine service continuity as soon as possible
Link with the Clinical Commissioning Group locally, Social care, local authorities in co-ordinating services.
The Ambulance Service
The ambulance service has responsibility for co-ordinating the on-site healthcare, and determines the hospitals to which injured persons are taken.
It is the Ambulance Service responsibility to:
Co-ordinate the NHS response at the scene of a major incident
Nominate and alert receiving hospitals and other NHS agencies
Provide treatment, stabilisation, care and transport of those injured at the scene
Provide transport, medical staff, communications and equipment at the scene
Transport patients who need further treatment to receiving hospitals
Establish effective triage point and determine the priorities for evacuation of the injured to hospitals
Provide liaison and communications with receiving hospitals
Maintain emergency and routine cover for the rest of the County.
Public Health England (PHE)
Ensures there is a comprehensive EPRR system that operates for public health at all levels and assure itself that the system is fit for purpose.
Provides specialist specialist/medical advice and support, in the event of a major public health emergency or CBRN incident.
Leads the mobilisation of PHE in the event of an emergency or incident.

Works together with the NHS at all levels and where appropriate develop joint response plans. Delivers public health services including, but not limited to, surveillance, intelligence gathering, risk assessment, scientific and technical advice, and microbiology services to emergency responders, Government and the public during emergencies, at all levels.
Participate in and provide specialist expert public health input to national, sub-national and LHRP planning for emergencies.
Scientific and Technical Advice Cell (STAC)

A Scientific and Technical Advice Cell (STAC) may be established during an incident to bring together technical experts from those agencies involved in the response to provide advice to the Gold Commander where there may be wider health and/or environmental consequences.

1A STAC can comprise of a number of specialists drawn from across the region or national specialists of the Health Protection Agency, Environment Agency, Animal Health, food Standards Agency and others. It should be recognised that a STAC will comprise of those specialists appropriate to the incident type and that the precise make up will vary between incidents.
The STAC is a strategic group. Its main purposes are to:-
Take advice on the health aspects of the incident from a range of experts
Provide advice to the Police Incident Commander on the health consequences of the incident including the consequences of any evacuation or containment policies.
Agree with the Police Incident Commander on the advice to be given to the public on the health aspects of the incident
Keep a written record of decisions made and the reasons for those decisions.

The deployment of a STAC will be at the formal request of the Police Gold Commander and therefore its full Operational Doctrine is covered by the ERF STAC plan a copy which is held in the Incident Control Room.
The Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC)
Lead Government role.

Takes control of the NHS resources in England in the event of a complex and significant emergency, including those on a national and international scale, through its Emergency Preparedness Division Coordinating Centre.
Provides the co-ordination and focal point for the NHS and supports the Health Ministers and Secretary of State.
Co-ordinates with the health departments in the developed administrations where health is a fully developed function.

Any response to a major incident relies on effective communication and teamwork with partner agencies (also referred to as category 1 and 2 responders under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004). The roles of category 1 responders in the event of a major incident are:
National Level

Cabinet Office Briefing Rooms (COBR) is a coordination facility of the Government that is activated in cases of national or regional emergency or crisis, or during events abroad with major implications for the UK.

The purpose of COBR is to enable the prime Minister, senior Ministers and key government officials to obtain vital information about an incident and to secure lines of communication to the police and other emergency services, MOD, hospitals, and all relevant branches of government.
The Environment Agency (EA)

Have primary responsibilities for the environmental protection of water, land and air in England and Wales. The EA has key responsibilities for maintaining and operating flood defences on rivers and coastlines. These responsibilities cover direct, remedial action to prevent and mitigate the effects of the incident, to provide specialist advice, to give warnings to those likely to be affected, to monitor the effects of an incident and to investigate its cause. The EA also collects evidence for future enforcement on cost recovery. It plays a part in the UK Government's response to overseas nuclear incidents.
The Military

Provide assistance in the response to an incident if there is a threat to life. The immediate assistance the Military is able to provide will depend upon the resources available at the time. The requests for assistance will normally be made at the county or regional level.
Health and Safety Executive (HSE)

Ensures the health and safety of people in their workplaces (including the responding emergency services), as well as its regulatory role in sites such as nuclear installations, hospitals, school and railway safety, and its specialist expertise in CBRN and major hazard industrial sites.
Plan awareness

Every member of staff plays a vital role in ensuring a professional NHS response to crisis. As such, it is essential that members of staff are aware of and have access to the plan and its content (including their role in an incident).
5.1.1 All wards, patient areas and departments within the Trust are required to support the plan with service level plans specific to their areas.
5.1.2 These will be held within that area and remain the responsibility of the departmental lead/manager to update, review and disseminate.
Emergencies

5.2.1 The definition of emergency is concerned with consequences, rather than cause or source. Therefore, an emergency inside or outside the UK is covered by this definition, provided it has consequences inside the UK.
5.2.2 The Civil Contingencies Act (2004) defines a major Incident as:

“An event or situation which threatens serious damage to human welfare in a place in the UK, the environment of a place in the UK, or war or terrorism which threatens serious damage to the security of the UK.”
5.2.3 The definition of a major incident is defined as:
‘a serious event or situation, with a range of significant impacts, which requires special arrangements to be implemented by one or more emergency responder organisations'
Cabinet Office 2016-17
5.2.4 Major Incident is a term used to describe an event or incident that requires the implementation of special arrangements in order to manage the situation effectively.
5.2.5 For the NHS, a major incident is the term in general use. However, the term ‘emergency' may be used instead of incident.
5.2.6 For the NHS, the NHS England EPRR Framework defines a major incident as:

“Any occurrence which presents a serious threat to the health of the community, disruption to the service or causes (or is likely to cause) such numbers or types of casualties as to require special arrangements to be implemented by hospitals, ambulance trusts or primary care organisations”.

5.2.7 Individual NHS organisations can self-declare a major incident when their own facilities and/or resources, or those of its neighbours are overwhelmed, but it does not necessarily mean that it is a major incident for all or any other organisation.
Types of incidents
5.3.1  The following list provides commonly used classifications of types of incident. This list is not exhaustive and other classifications may be used as appropriate.
Business continuity incidents – fire, breakdown of utilities, significant equipment failure, hospital acquired infections
Big Bang: A sudden emergency; instant and out of nowhere, immediately recognisable; quick development e.g. a train crash
Rising Tide: A developing incident e.g. infectious disease pandemic / epidemic
Cloud on the Horizon: Serious threat elsewhere needing preparatory action.
Headline News: Public or media alarm about an impending situation, reputation management issues.
*Chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and explosives (CBRNE) –the actual or threatened dispersal of CBRNe material with deliberate criminal, malicious or murderous intent.
*HAZMAT – accidental incident involving hazardous materials.
Environmental: Weather/Pollution.
Cyber-attacks – attacks on systems (infrastructure or confidential data) to cause disruption, reputational and financial damage.

Mass casualty – ‘considered in accordance with the scale and complexities of the incident, as well as the current capacity within the system, paying particular reference to the numbers of P1 and P2s'.
National threat levels

5.4.1 National threat levels are designed to give a broad indication of the likelihood of a terrorist attack. The Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (JTAC), is based at MI5's headquarters in London, and is comprised of 16 government departments and agencies to determine the current threat level to the UK, through the use of.
Available intelligence
Terrorist Capability
Terrorist intentions
Timescale
5.4.2 The National threat levels are:
Critical - an attack is expected imminently
Severe - an attack is highly likely
Substantial - an attack is a strong possibility
Moderate - an attack is possible but not likely
Low - an attack is unlikely
Alerting

5.5.1 In the Health Service, organisations are most likely to be alerted to a major incident by the Ambulance Service who has specific responsibilities and procedures for this. In this situation, the on-call Director should assess the incident and make a decision as to whether the situation constitutes a major incident for the Trust.

5.5.2 Emergency Services at scene will make judgements as to the nearest hospital or the best able to receive casualties. The chosen hospital is called the “Receiving hospital” and a number of others may be given the role of “Supporting hospital”.
5.5.3 This alerts the locality to the possibility of self-presenting casualties and informs the supporting hospitals that they may be steeped up to receiving status.

5.5.4 The decision to declare a major incident and mount an appropriate response remains the decision of the organisation. The procedure and protocols outlines in this plan can be used to respond to an incident without the requirements of a formal declaration.
5.5.5 A Major Incident may be declared by either external or internal sources:-
Internal and external alerting in an incident

table_items.text: Externally: Ambulance Control declares a major incident or potential for one, notifying trust switchboard.
Switchboard operator ‘record and repeat' incident details with ambulance control. Switchboard then contacts senior manager and director on call, and clinical site Coordinators, relaying the details.
Externally: Ambulance Control may use its direct link to notify the hospital Emergency Department through the Red Phone in ED.
A member of the ED Department informs Switchboard, who will verify the notification with Ambulance Control. On verification action followed above.
Externally: Another source e.g. police, fire service, member of the public.
Switchboard operator must verify the notification with Ambulance Control then action as above

Internally: The Chief Executive / Deputy, Director / Director on call, Senior Manager on Call / Emergency Department Consultant where the arrival of casualties occurs before receipt of a notification of a major incident.
Switchboard operator records all details provided then verifies the notification with an authorised manager. On verification, action as above.

data.text: 5.6.1 The Emergency Department Consultant may feel the need to activate the plan in certain circumstances, should the Consultant deem this necessary they should in- hours consult the Chief Executive/ Managing Director / Director of Operations, out of hours the On-Call Director of the Trust. If the decision taken is to activate the plan, the Nurse in charge of ED must notify switchboard.
5.6.2 There are several reasons why this could happen:

table_items.text: Self-presentation of casualties from one or more incidents at ED in a short space of time without notification from the emergency services.

The self-presentation of patients to ED reception who may be contaminated with chemical, biological, nuclear or radioactive agents, it will then be necessary to activate the Trust's CBRN plan and decontamination procedure.

The ED may well be able to deal with a road traffic accident involving a number of casualties, without calling a Major Incident. This will be left entirely to the discretion of the ED Consultant on duty at that time.

data.text: NHS standard incident declaration message
5.7.1  The NHS standard messages to be used, in connection with the declaration of an incident includes:

This alerts the NHS that a major incident may need to be declared. Major Incident Standby is to involve the participating NHS organisations in making preparatory arrangements appropriate to the incident
Organisations need to activate their Major Incident Plans and mobilise additional resources
This cancels either of the first two
messages at any time All receiving hospitals are alerted as soon as all live

casualties have been removed from site. Whilst the ambulance service and other organisations may have stood down at this point, it is the responsibility of each organisation to access when it is suitable for their own organisation to stand down.
When the organisation stands down, this must be effectivly communicated in a timely manner to all partners.

Note: Departments must not Stand Down until they are told to do so. This message will only come from the Incident Management Team or via a Trust-wide email. This instruction will only be given when there are no more casualties expected from the site. Be  prepared,  this  could  be  many  hours  after  the  scene  of  the  incident  has  been evacuated and / or the hospital is back to a manageable capacity.
Receipt of initial notification On receipt of a STANDBY alert:

table_items.text: Switchboard will call the on call ED Consultant, Director / Executive and Senior Manager who will be given as much information as possible about the major incident.

The ED Consultant will: I) assess as to whether to initiate the appropriate steps to prepare the Emergency Department for its response to the major incident pending notification of the on call Executive / Director's and Senior Managers decision at step 3. II) be available to liaise with the on call Director if required

The on call Executive /Director will, as appropriate, in liaison with the ED Consultant: I) make a decision as to whether the Incident Control Team should be mobilised II) Assess the likely requirement of any call out of staff.
The On call Executive / Director will relay their decision at step 3 to switchboard and the ED Consultant. If NO, go to step 5; if YES, step 6
If the on-call Executive / Director's decision at step 3 is ‘NO', switchboard notifies on-call Senior Manager who decides when to alert / forewarn other on-call managers.
If the on-call Executive / Director subsequently authorises Major Incident Declared – Activate Plan, go to step 6. If not, Major Incident Standby alert is terminated.

If the on-call Executive / Director's decision at step 3 is ‘YES' he/she becomes Incident Executive and switchboard notifies : (i) ED Consultant who prepares the Emergency Department (ii) activates call out cascade (iii) on-call Senior Manager who becomes Incident Manager and (a) sets up Hospital Incident Control Room (b) nominates staff for designated Major Incident roles for Hospital Incident Control Room Manager

data.text: On receipt of a major incident declared - activate plan alert:
the hospital switchboard operators will notify the on-call Director and proceed to step 6 above
On call executive / director
5.10.1 The on-call Executive / Director:

Will  ensure  that  the  Chief  Executive  (or  Deputy  if  not  available),  other Director's and local Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) are informed of the major incident alert as soon as is practicable

The on-call Director may not be in a position to take on the role of Incident Executive but must ensure that the role is expressly transferred to a suitably trained Director or Senior Manager and that this is recorded in the Major Incident Log book.
The on-call Director is also responsible for ensuring that the Chief Executive (or deputy) and, where appropriate, the CCG and Public Health England is alerted and notified when the incident is over.
Loggist
5.11.1 A comprehensive Log must be kept of all events, information received and the actions and decisions of key individuals in response to the incident.
EMERGENCY LOG BOOK (ELB) 101

From the time of notification of the major incident alert and throughout until the declaration  of  major  incident  stand  down,  notification  of  which  must  also  be documented, all Trust staff involved in the major incident must keep a record of their activities and actions on their own Major Incident Log, as requested, copies made available to the Incident Control Team.
5.11.2 In the first instance, a trained loggist will be allocated to:
Incident Director
Incident Manager
Medical Controller
Nursing Controller
5.11.3 The log must be a complete and continuous record of all actions/decisions and any resulting issues made as well as messages received. I.e. telephone calls received and made.
I Decisions made and actions taken and any resulting issues

III Verbal instructions and any non-verbal (i.e. nodding or shaking of head)

5.11.4 If dictation machines are used by a member of staff to record actions and/or decisions, they should ensure that these are typed up on a regular basis during the major incident and checked for accuracy. The recorded tapes must be marked to identify their contents and retained in their original state and returned to the maker with the draft hard record.
5.11.6 If notes or maps are utilised these must be documented within the log.

5.11.7 In addition to the designated Loggist, a member of staff (a ‘scribe') may be nominated to ‘shadow' a member of staff with a key role in the management of a major incident and record their activities in the Major Incident Diary Log. The Loggers and scribes should record their name and status on the Major Incident documentation and record the times when they began and concluded their role. Where possible and without compromising the management of the major incident, the member of staff and their scribe should liaise on a regular basis during the major incident to agree the accuracy of the Logger/scribes' entries in the Emergency Log Book. If this is not possible during the major incident, this should be completed within 24hrs of declaration of the major incident stand down.
5.11.8 The Emergency Log Book (ELB) 101 must:
Be signed by all persons in attendance
Be signed and dated by the loggist of any entries to include the scribe
Be completed in permanent black ink and legibly
Explain acronyms where first recorded
Include details of dates and times of all information given and received (with the source), the decisions made with contributors and reasons together with the action taken.
No erasures
No leaves must be torn out of book
No blank spaces – rule them through
No overwriting
No writing above or below lined area

5.11.9 At the end of each action in the log a Z score and signature is to be added underneath the documentation so no alterations can be made at a later date. All documentation is to be kept safe and retained for evidence for any future proceedings.
The log and all paper work becomes a legal documentation and could be used at a later date in a Public Enquiry or other legal proceedings.
Incident response and phases
Initial assessment of the situation

6.1.1 The Executive / Managing Director / Director On-Call (Gold), with input from Clinical Site Coordinators, Senior Manager on call and other key personnel as required (e.g. Senior Clinician, Estates); will make the initial assessment of the situation:

Consider the trust critical business functions.
Maintain a clear perspective on events, risks & possible consequences.
Communicate quickly and effectively (Internally/Externally). Media attention.
Implement the Command & Control arrangements.
Start a log, ensuring actions & decisions are recorded.
Ensure that the Chief Executive (or Deputy) / Managing Director is informed of the incident alert as soon as is practicable.

If the Executive / Director / Director on-call is not in a position to take on the role of Incident director he/she must ensure that the role is transferred to a suitably trained Director or Senior Manager and that this is recorded.

6.1.3 The Trust must plan to handle incidents in which its own facilities - or neighbouring ones - may be overwhelmed. The Trust itself may be affected by its own internal incident or by an external incident that impairs its ability to work normally
6.1.4 The Trust can self-declare a major incident when their own facilities and/or resources, or those of its neighbours are overwhelmed, if so, the Trust is responsible for alerting other agencies.

6.1.5 In addition, there are pre-planned major events, for example, demonstrations, sports fixtures, air shows etc. that may require a response. There may also be events occurring on a national scale, for example fuel strikes, pandemic or multiple events that require the collective capability of the NHS nationally.

6.1.7  A major incident for the Trust will only be declared if, in the Trust's assessment, an incident requires a response outside of its normal services and resources or affects its ability to provide normal levels of services and resources. The declaration of an internal major incident by other agencies does not necessarily mean that the Trust will be affected, for instance a local agency may declare a major incident but not require any assistance from the Trust and the incident site itself has not compromised any of the Trust's services.

data.text: Casualty triage
6.4.1 There are typically four groups of patients who are likely to make demands upon the NHS in a major incident:
Those seriously ill or injured as a direct result of the incident

Those affected by the incident who, although not obviously or immediately suffering from serious illness or injury, need assessment, diagnosis, advice or treatment and may need subsequent monitoring and on-going support that can often be better provided in a non-acute or primary care setting.
People who are neither ill nor injured but require information, advice and reassurance (the ‘worried well').

Continued Service for those who fall acutely ill (i.e. heart attack) but are not part of the incident and those patients in the community affected by the loss of service due to the impact of the incident and its responses.

Command and control tiers
Vertical chain of command

7.1.2 Each organisation has a vertical chain of command at the scene of the incident and within individual organisations. Commands emanate from the on-call Director who acts as the Trusts Strategic (Gold) Commander and are implemented in a controlled way. It is not desirable for command to repeatedly change hands with the progressive arrival of more senior managers as this will interrupt the continuity of management. Ideally the command should change hands periodically, in the case of this Trust this would probably be the on-call Director to the Chief Executive or nominated deputy as soon as they are available. The Trust Strategic (Gold) Commander should interact with other Trust managers at regular intervals in order to ensure a good communications flow.
7.1.3 In response to a Major Incident the Trust will implement three levels of command and Control:
Gold (Strategic) Command
Silver (Tactical) Command

Internal command and control structure
7.3.1 Gold Command (Strategic Command),

Gold Command (Strategic Command) which comprises the Site Managing Director and all available Directors including the Incident Executive. This Team is responsible for the strategic management of the major incident and plays an advisory role to the Incident Control Team.
7.3.2 Tactical command (silver) hospital incident control centre team:

Silver Command (Tactical Command) which refers to those who are responsible for formulating  the  tactics  to  be  adopted  by  the  service  to  achieve  the  strategic direction set by strategic command. Tactical command will oversee but will not be directly involved in providing the operational response to the incident.
7.3.3 Operational control level (bronze):

The term ‘Bronze' operational refers to those who will provide the main operational response to an incident and control the resources of their respective service within a specific area of the incident. They will implement the tactics defined by Silver ‘tactical' Control.
7.3.4 Structure
During times of severe pressure and when responding to critical/major incident, ALL responding organisations form a structured approach which provides;
Clear leadership;
Accountable decision making; and
Accurate, up to date and far-reaching communication.
This is commonly known as the three tiered ‘command and control' structure. With three ascending levels: Operational ‘Bronze', Tactical ‘Silver' and Strategic ‘Gold'.
7.3.5 Structure within the Trust
Membership
Depending on the magnitude and type of the incident, membership at each level will differ.
7.3.6 Location of response
Both Gold and Silver command teams will operate from designated Incident Control Centre (ICC). These are pre-located and pre-set with equipment that might be needed to support a response.
Hospital incident control centre locations
Basildon Hospital: st floor, above the Emergency Department Southend Hospital: Nerve Centre First Floor Prittlewell Wing
Broomfield Hospital: At the Rear of the Emergency Department, Zone A, Level 2 opposite Site office.
External command and control structure
7.5.1 Strategic Co-ordinating Group SCG (Gold)

The Strategic Co-ordinating Group (Gold Control) is a strategic multi-agency group that will look at the wider impact of the incident and make any high level strategic decisions. The location of Gold Control will depend on the location and nature of the incident although it is usually located in the main Police Headquarters for the area where the major incident occurred. A representative from the NHS, usually the on call NHS England and Improvement or CCG will be asked to attend. However if the major incident is affecting one location in particular, the local CCG may be asked to send a senior representative, usually the Chief Executive or Director of Public Health.
A Director from this Trust may be requested to attend Gold Control.
7.5.2 Tactical Co-ordinating Group TCG (Silver)

Silver Control is the Incident Control Team convened and located within each agency / organisation involved, to manage that agencies / organisations response at a tactical level and is led by the ‘Silver' Commander. The Silver Control of each agency / organisation involved communicates with Gold Control direct and with the Silver Controls of the other agencies / organisations if required.
7.5.3 Operational (Bronze)

Bronze Control refers to the staff of each agency / organisation involved (to include the Trust) who are actively involved in responding to the major incident at an operational level. Bronze Control is led by the ‘Bronze Controller' or “Incident Controller” who is located within each agency. The Bronze Controller for each agency communicates with that agency's Silver Control as to the duties and activities required of Bronze Control and co-ordinates these. Communication received from other agencies by the Bronze Controller should be referred to that agency's Silver Control as they should have more information available about the incident than anyone working at Bronze level
Organisational arrangements
7.6.1 Irrespective of particular responsibilities of organisations and agencies who may be involved with the major incident response, the Trust will work to the following common objectives to:
Save life
Prevent escalation of the disaster
Relieve suffering
Safeguard the environment
Protect property
Facilitate criminal investigation and judicial, technical or other enquiries
Continue to maintain normal services at an appropriate level
Inform the public
Promote self-help and recovery
Restore normality as soon as possible
Evaluate the response and identify lessons to be learned
7.6.2 Specific roles and responsibilities
The Trust's specific roles and responsibilities during a major incident are to:
Provide a safe and secure environment for the assessment and treatment of patients
Provide a safe and secure environment for staff that will ensure the health, safety and welfare of staff including appropriate arrangements for the professional and personal indemnification of staff
Provide a clinical response including provision of general support and specific/specialist health care to all casualties, victims and responders

Liaise with the East of England Ambulance Service, NHS England and NHS Improvement (East of England), NHS Mid Essex (Lead) CCG and local CCGs, other hospitals, independent sector providers, and other agencies in order to manage the impact of the incident
Ensure that the hospital reviews all its essential functions throughout the
incident
Provide appropriate support to any designated receiving hospital or other neighbouring service that is substantially affected
Provide limited decontamination facilities and personal protective equipment to manage contaminated self-presenting casualties
Make arrangements to reflect national guidance from the Home Office for dealing with the bodies of contaminated patients who die at the hospital
Liaise with activated health emergency control centres and/or on call NHSE/CCG Officers as appropriate
Maintain communications with relatives and friends of existing patients and those from the incident, the Police Casualty Bureau, the local community, the
media and VIPs.

data.text: Incident situation report

8.4.1  During a Major Incident, the trust will be required to collate and submit situation reports to NHS England and Commissioners. The Silver team will be responsible for collating this information with support from Bronze leads. An algorithm for information requests will be set by NHS England and Commissioners at the time of the incident.
Staffing
Calling in more staff

9.1.1 A major incident can occur at any time, day or night and all staff must be prepared to work in a different location, work different shifts and attend even when not on call or on duty. Certain incidents may require staff to attend another site, work in an unfamiliar area or work a different shift. In the event of a major incident it may be necessary to call in additional staff.
9.1.2 Switchboard will NOT be responsible for contacting members of staff not identified as part of the Major Incident communications cascade list.

9.1.3 Individual areas are responsible for calling in additional staff however, extra staff should not be called in automatically, a decision should be made as to whether extra staff are needed, based upon the available information.
9.1.4 Once notified of a Major Incident, it is the responsibility of the most senior member of staff in each area to establish whether they have adequate staffing levels.

9.1.5 It is important that those managing the response for a particular area ensure staff availability throughout the incident. This will involve a phased call out after an assessment of the likely duration of the incident has been obtained from the Incident Control Team.
9.1.6 It is the responsibility of each member of staff to ensure that any changes to their personal contact details are given to their Line Manager.
Shift arrangements
9.2.1 Incident Director has responsibility for ensuring arrangements are reasonable, seeking advice from Human resources as necessary.
9.2.2 Irrespective of the length of the incident it is vital staff are given sufficient breaks to prevent fatigue and minimise the effects of stress. Staff should:
Not work a period in excess of 12 hours at any one time
At a minimum, take a  minute break everyhours on duty
Working flexibly
9.3.1 This Trust may need staff to work flexibly to enable an effective response, ensuring that staffs with the required skills are deployed to deliver priority services.
9.3.2 Working flexibly will require managers to consider:
Relocating staff to work at other locations,
Staff working different hours (including those on fixed hours),
Staff undertaking different duties
Roles that can be undertaken from home or another remote location
Staff Identity Cards/Action Cards

9.3.3 All Trust staff must wear their staff identity cards visibly throughout the major incident. Wherever possible staff will be deployed using action cards. The action cards describe the role/responsibilities of the designated Trust staff and will be distributed from the Hospital Incident Control Room where they must be returned within 24 hours of stand down of the major incident.

9.3.4 In an incident situation staff should report for duty wearing their normal uniform. This will prevent confusion and will ensure staff are not challenged by security staff when trying to access the hospital.
9.3.5 Tabards will be issued to key personnel to identify them in their major incident role. Staff wearing tabards should also display their own ID badge for ease of recognition.

9.3.6 Failure to wear ID badges may result in a delay in gaining access to critical areas. Staff should not leave their ID badges at their place of work, as they may be required to present them on arrival at work in an incident.
Ceasing duty
9.4.1  No member of Trust staff may go off duty during a major incident without, as appropriate, the permission of the Incident Manager or their departmental manager.
Incident support
Debrief purpose

10.1.1 Debriefing is a critical element of the Major Incident response and recovery process. Correctly conducted and timely de-briefing will ensure that the effectiveness of the response is critically evaluated and that staff welfare is monitored and action taken at the earliest opportunity.

10.1.2 Staff should be encouraged to discuss issues or concerns, but should also be given the opportunity to feed back in detail and anonymously if desired, as part of the full debrief process. De-Briefs should not be allowed to become over-emotional, individualised or confrontational.
10.1.3 The whole debrief process should be seen to be a positive effort to learn the lessons in an open and honest way.
Key objectives of the debrief
Identify the positive points and what worked well
Identify challenging aspects and consider what didn't work well
Identify learning points
Agree an implementation programme for the identified learning points to secure improved performance in the future.
Types of debrief

a) Hot debrief – immediately after the incident or period of duty to ensure that immediate lessons identified and good practice are captured. Should include all individuals involved with the incident response.
b) Cold debrief – within two weeks post incident, to identify areas for improvement
or good practice.
c) Multi-agency debrief to capture partnership learning. Organised by lead responding organisation. Health debrief organised by NHS England.

d) Post incident reports: written by the trust Emergency Planning Team. The report will contain an action log and plan for areas of improvement. This will be distributed to relevant partners, internally; the trust board and emergency preparedness group.
Who will conduct the initial debrief

10.4.1 Overall responsibility for the debrief will be assumed by the Incident Director. Operational (Bronze) Leads to conduct internal departmental ‘Hot' debriefs with all staff as soon as possible after the incident. Silver and gold commander to undertake hot debriefs for their response teams.

10.4.2 For the overall cold debrief, it is an option for the incident director/executive director to appoint an individual who has not had substantial direct involvement in the incident itself to conduct the debrief and produce the report. The trust emergency planning team can support in the debrief function as required.
10.4.3 Where possible, the appointment of an additional person to record and summarise lessons identified may prove particularly beneficial.
Social psychological and psychiatric support
Overview

11.1.1 Any traumatic incident or disaster, whether natural or man-made, has a psychological impact on those involved – survivors, the bereaved, witnesses, rescuers, responders and health professionals, and their families, relatives, friends and workmates
11.1.2 Patients, relatives and staff may require support to help them cope with a variety of symptoms, many of which are a normal response to their experience.
11.1.3 Most of those affected will adjust gradually, over time – some will need more support than others.

11.1.4 Risk factors include the development of post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, anxiety disorder, or substance abuse include: proximity to the event, multiple stressors, a history of trauma, unresolved anxieties, and pre-existing chronic illness
Recognising the common response to a traumatic event

Difficulty in concentrating Shortened attention span Poor memory Disorientation Intrusive/unwanted memories Heightened alertness Difficulty in making decisions Difficulty in sleeping, poor sleep Bad dreams, nightmares
Tiredness, exhaustion Headache, other aches and pains Dizziness Nausea, gastrointestinal upset Rapid heart rate Profuse sweating Tremor, shaking Jaw clenching, teeth grinding

Emotional outbursts Increased argumentativeness Withdrawal, silence Temporary loss/increase in appetite Increased smoking/restarting smoking Overuse of alcohol, substance abuse Inability to rest Unnecessary risk-taking

data.text: Access to psychological support
11.3.1 Trust staff have access to counselling services through the Occupational Health Team. Additional services may be brought in depending on the nature and duration of the incident.

11.3.2 Individuals may need the supportive framework provided by social and psychological services in which they can come to terms with the effects of the disaster on their lives. Support may be needed both in the immediate aftermath of the incident and in the longer term.

11.3.3 There should be close cooperation between the mental health service and local authority social services in the provision of social, psychological and psychiatric support following a major incident. There is a crucial role for properly trained mental health personnel in the treatment and support of victims of all  ages,  their  families  and  carers,  and  of  staff  involved  in  the  response. Psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers and religious leaders may carry out this work.
Listen
Try to communicate clearly, openly, and with compassion:
Validate emotions – intense reactions and painful emotions are a common, understandable and expected response to a traumatic event
Keep your own experiences to yourself: remember, you do not know just how someone feels, though you may sometimes think that you do
Encourage those affected to rest, keep to their usual routines, and help them to identify ways to relax

Encourage those affected to identify and use other sources of support to talk through their experiences and responses – family and friends, GP services, spiritual, religious, community or cultural networks, counselling services.
Indications for referral to a mental health professional
Persistent non-resolving symptoms that interfere with daily living
Symptoms severe enough to prevent self-care: not eating, not
washing/bathing, not changing clothes
Problematic use of alcohol or drugs
Those with suicidal or homicidal thoughts, feelings or plans
Domestic violence, child abuse or elder abuse
Those with symptoms of mental illness – either pre-existing, or newly developed
Training and exercising

12.1.1 The Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response team will provide/coordinate training as requested by Departments, and ensure that the relevant staff have access to any external courses, such as loggist training and Strategic Leadership in a Crisis.

12.1.2 Senior managers and Clinicians in each Care Group are responsible for ensuring that all staff whom they are responsible for have received induction and refresher training to prepare them for their role in a major incident. Training should include:
Familiarisation of all staff, including Clinicians, with the major Incident Plan and their role in it.
Training in the use of emergency communications equipment as appropriate.

12.1.3 Training for a major incident involves a significant investment in cost, time and resources. Nevertheless, to effectively manage an incident, the Trust must be fully committed to training for responding to major incidents or business continuity issues. Major incident training will reflect normal good training practice and will vary from general awareness to specific training for staff with key roles.
Exercising
12.1.1 In order to test the readiness of the hospital and to assess the effectiveness of the training, a number of exercises will be held each year, with written evaluations and actions.

12.1.2 The planning of these programmes is the responsibility of the Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response team in conjunction with the Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Strategic committee.

12.1.3 This plan will also be regularly exercised both internally and externally with other agencies. A detailed debrief report will be produced following such exercises and any major lessons learnt will be incorporated into the Plan.
12.1.4 It is important that staff have the opportunity to practice procedures and to become familiar with equipment (including that used in communications) and the staff whom they will be working.
12.1.5 For example:

Practical exercises of varying complexity, involving people and equipment, to test availability, communications systems, the ability to put the plan into operation and the general capacity to handle a major incident.
Table-top exercises, to test the management response and to review procedures.
Minimum requirements, the Trust will be required to undertake
A ‘live' exercise every three years
A ‘table top' exercise every year
A test of communications cascade every six months (Communications Exercise – COMMEX).
12.2.1 A report is produced after each exercise and presented to the Emergency Preparedness and Business Steering Committee, for forward circulation.

12.2.2 Trust staff will, wherever practicable, be given the opportunity to participate in an exercise, thus building confidence, familiarity with procedures and, in multi-agency exercises, relationships with external agencies.
12.2.3 Every effort will be made by the Trust to ensure participation in multi-agency exercises and tests.
Commex (communication exercise)
What is a commex?

A COMMEX exercise is a communications practice exercise for major incidents, which assesses the Trust's ability to contact and make available sufficient staff 24/7 in the event of a Major Incident. It does not involve real or “pretend” casualties and staff contacted are not required to come to the hospital or, if already on site, take up their major incident positions in the hospital, report to Silver Incident Control or activate/move resources. The only actions required are to:
Cascade the message as per the action cards,
Contact staff and obtain their availability and estimated
